bibl.title: Report from Alexander N. Stark to the Surgeon General, July 31, 1900

div1.p: Stark takes over duties as Chief Sanitary Officer after Kean is taken ill by yellow fever. Stark describes his preventative measures against the spreading of the disease. He commends numerous individuals for their help in the epidemic. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report from Alexander N. Stark to the Surgeon General, July 31, 1900
div1.opener:
Starks second report on the YF epidemic in
Quemados - summer 1900
Jul 31, 1900
See Havards
report
POST HOSPITAL
COLUMBIA BARRACKS, CUBA.
To be considered. In connection with Stark Report June to July
July 31st, 1900.
To the Surgeon General,
U.S. Army,
(Through Chief Surgeon of the Division)
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to submit the following supplement to the
Report on Yellow Fever at Quemados, Cuba, and Columbia Barracks, rend-
ered June 15th, 1900.

A few days after submitting the report referred to above,
Major J. R. Kean, U.S.V., Chief Surgeon of the Department, fell a
victim to the disease in the execution of his duty as Chief Sanitary
Officer of the Municipality, and the duties of his office devolved
upon me in addition to my own.

Plans had already been made by Major Kean to move the non-
immune element from the zone of infection, but his illness prevent-
ed him from perfecting his plans.

The municipality being under military law, and General Lee
having placed the control of the epidemic in my hands, with authority
to do as was deemed best, the problem presented none of the difficult-
ies that confront a board of health in the United States.

A camp had been prepared at a distance of two miles from
Quemados and to this camp were moved all non-immunes, irrespective
of age, sex, or nationality.

Saloons, houses of prostitution, and all resorts where one
could contract the disease, were closed, and the town ceased to be
an attraction for soldiers and civilian employes.

The Provost Guard that had patrolled the town was withdrawn
2
and the Rural Guard was placed on duty with orders to arrest all
soldiers and civilian employes found within the town.

Orders had already been issued by the Post Commander
to all within the post prohibiting any communication with the
town, but as is the case with all such orders the soldiers managed
to evade the chain of sentries until the Rural Guard was placed in
control.

The saloonkeepers and others in the non-immune camp did all
in their power to render the quarantine ineffective, but soon gave
in, and in a short time the epidemic was over.

Cases continued to occur now and again in the post among
the soldiers and civilian employes, but investigation in every in-
stance disclosed the fact that the victim had eluded the guard
and passed a night in Havana or in Quemados.

In each case the barrack was disinfected, and no case
originated within the post.

It was found that without the assistance of the men it was
futile to attempt to control the restless spirits in such a large
community, and the experiment of drenching the clothing and beds of
all in the barrack during the routine of disinfection was tried with
the object of rendering all uncomfortable for the night and thereby
causing resentment against any culprit who brought the calamity
upon them. The result of this experiment exceeded my most sanguine
hopes, and it is rare that any soldier has the fortitude to brave
a hundred angry men for the sake of a visit to town.

The majority of all cases have been civilians and as the
work demanding their presence approaches its termination this un-
desirable and dangerous element will be eliminated soon.

The non-immunes will not be allowed to re-occupy their
houses till November 15th, and the saloons and other resorts will
be closed indefinitely probably.

In my first report the origin of the epidemic was attrib-
uted to a latent infection requiring only suitable conditions,
and the fact that the disease has appeared in nearly all localities
in the Island at the same time has strengthened my belief.

The inmates of clean and filthy houses have been attack-
ed impartially.

A large combined steam and formaline disinfector has been
added to our equipment, and in addition to affording a greater
sense of security, has saved much property that otherwise would
have been burned.

In Quemados and Columbia Barracks there have been forty-
one cases up to date with twelve deaths.

Everyone in authority has done all in their power toward
the suppression of the epidemic.

I cannot too strongly commend to your consideration
Acting Assistant Surgeon Ames, who cared for the patients, Acting
Assistant Surgeon Lazear, who made the microscopical and chemical
tests, Acting Assistant Surgeon Pinto, who promptly recognized the
cases in the Receiving Ward, Privates Colby, Fanning, Folk and Lambert
Hospital Corps, U.S.A., who nursed the cases, and Contract Nurses,
Ella M. Gillen, Kate S.M. Ledlie, Ella Cook and Alice M. Gillette.

It is a source of great gratification that no one connect-
ed with the hospital hesitated at any duty required or showed the
slightest fear in the presence of the dread disease.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, A. N. Stark. Capt. & Asst. Surg. U.S.A.,
Surgeon.
